title: Chapter 1 Review - Practice & Application
description: Review and practice everything from Chapter 1

content.instructions: Test your knowledge of pronouns, verb attachment, and adjectives from lessons 1-4.

exercises.question: How do you say 'We are going home' in Dholuo?
exercises.explanation: 'Wan' (we) becomes 'Wa' when attached to verbs, plus 'dhi' (go) plus 'dala' (home)

exercises.question: What does 'nyathi maduong'' mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Nyathi' means baby, 'ma' is a linking particle, 'duong'' means big

exercises.question: How do you say 'I am going' in Dholuo?
exercises.explanation: Remove 'n' from 'An' (I) and attach 'A' to 'dhi' (go) to get 'Adhi'

exercises.question: Which pronoun becomes 'Gi' when attached to verbs?
exercises.explanation: 'Gin' (they) becomes 'Gi' when you remove the 'n' and attach it to verbs

exercises.question: What does 'matin' mean in 'nyathi matin'?
exercises.explanation: 'Tin' means small or little, so 'nyathi matin' means 'small baby'

exercises.question: How do you say 'You (plural) are cooking' in Dholuo?
What does 'be' mean in Dholuo?
exercises.explanation: 'Be' is the short form of 'bende' which means 'also' or 'as well'

exercises.question: In 'Gin be giherou', what does 'u' represent?
exercises.explanation: 'U' at the end of the verb shows the object is 'you (plural)' - from 'Un'

exercises.question: What is unique about the third person singular 'En' when used as a subject?
exercises.explanation: When 'En' is the subject of a verb, it takes the form 'O', like in 'Odhi' (he/she goes)

exercises.question: How do you say 'here' in Dholuo?
exercises.explanation: 'Ka' means 'here', as in 'Matin ni ka' (the small one is here)

exercises.question: How do you respond to 'Oyaore' (good morning)?
exercises.explanation: When greeted with 'Oyaore', you respond with 'Oyaore ahinya' - the word 'ahinya' means 'verily' or 'a lot'

exercises.question: What does 'Ere wach?' literally mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Ere' means 'where' and 'wach' means 'word' or 'news', so literally it asks 'Where is the news?' but means 'What's up?'

exercises.question: If someone asks 'Ichiew nade?', what are they asking?
exercises.explanation: 'Chiew' means 'to wake up' and 'nade' means 'how', so 'Ichiew nade?' means 'How did you wake up?'

content.instructions: Write a greeting to the world in Dholuo using what you've learned. Start by greeting everyone, ask how they are, share how you're doing, and say goodbye politely.
prompts: Start by greeting everyone: 'Amosou jopiny' (I greet you, people of the world)
Ask how they're doing: 'Udhi nade?' or 'Untie?' or 'Ungima?'
Share how you're doing: 'An adhi maber' or 'An antie' or 'An angima'
content.example: Amosou jopiny! Udhi nade? An adhi maber. Oritu ahinya!

content.instructions: Listen to the audio clip and answer the questions below. You can replay the audio up to 3 times.
content.transcript: An Otieno. Adhi limogi. Gin be gidhi dala. Nyathi maduong' otedo maber.
content.translation: I am Otieno. I'm going to visit them. They are also going home. The big child cooked well.

questions.question: What is the speaker's name?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'An Otieno' meaning 'I am Otieno'

questions.question: Where is the speaker going?
questions.explanation: 'Adhi limogi' means 'I'm going to visit them'

questions.question: Who cooked well?
questions.explanation: 'Nyathi maduong' otedo maber' means 'The big child cooked well'

content.congratulations: Excellent work! You've completed Chapter 1 and learned the fundamentals of Dholuo.
content.summary: In this chapter you learned: basic pronouns (An, In, En, Wan, Un, Gin), how to attach pronouns to verbs, basic adjectives (ber, rach, duong', tin), and essential vocabulary for introductions.
content.next_steps: Ready for Chapter 2? You'll learn about family members, possessive pronouns, and everyday activities!
